answer_html: (That’s because calculating the inverse of a matrix A is an overkill here, there is faster ways of finding x that don’t require the matrix inverse.)
answer_latex:
(That's because calculating the inverse
of a matrix \emph{A} is an overkill here, there is faster ways of

hints_html: What is the special Matlab command for solving a linear system?
hints_latex: What is the special Matlab command for solving a linear system?
hints_raw: What is the special Matlab command for solving a linear system?
question: A 27
sols_html:
If we have a linear system

\[\begin{aligned} A\mathbf{x}=\mathbf{b}\end{aligned}\]

then Matlab can solve this via the \ operator. Therefore if we type

x=A\b;

then the vector x produced by Matlab is the solution to the linear system.

Note. Since A is invertible, it is possible to get the solution by typing

x=inv(A)*b;

but you are generally discouraged from using the inv() operation in Matlab to solve linear systems. (That’s because calculating the inverse of a matrix A is an overkill here, there is faster ways of finding x that don’t require the matrix inverse.)
statement_html:
Suppose that A is an \(8 \times 8\) invertible matrix and b is a column vector with 8 entries. Both A and b have been entered into MATLAB. What commands would you use to compute the vector x that solves the linear system

\[\begin{aligned} A \mathbf{x} = \mathbf{b}?\end{aligned}\]
statement_raw:
Suppose that ''A'' is an <math> 8 \times 8 </math> invertible matrix and ''b'' is a column vector with 8 entries. Both ''A'' and ''b'' have been entered into MATLAB. What commands would you use to compute the vector '''x''' that solves the linear system

:<math> A \mathbf{x} = \mathbf{b}? </math>
